turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I suppose they are, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You're damned right they are.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: How much soda, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Just a squirt.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: That about right?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Perfect.  Thank you, Major.  And now let's drink a toast.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: What shall we drink to, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: To peace on earth.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: General Ripper, can I ask another question?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Ask away, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, General -- I was wondering, why are you doing this?  I mean why do you want to start the war?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I've given it alot of thought, Major.  Don't think I haven't.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.  I mean I didn't think you hadn't given it a lot of thought.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Do you remember what Clemenceau once said about war?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I don't think so, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: He said war was too important a matter to be left to Generals.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: When he said it, fifty years ago, he might have been right.  But today, war is too important to be left to the politicians. Do you follow me, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I'm trying to, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You see, Major, at this very moment, while we sit and chat, a decision is being made by the President in the War Room.  He knows that the enemy will pick up our planes on their radar in about twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But when they do, sir, won't they hit back with everything they've got?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: If we haven't taken any further action, they certainly will.  Doyyourhappen to remember the statistics on our casualties in the event of a full-scale enemy attack?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, I think I remember reading the report on that.  Wasn't it something like a hundred and sixty million?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: That's close enough, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But then why do you want to kill a hundred and sixty million of our people, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You're being dense, Major.  I certainly don't

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I suppose we might catch them off their guard.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Our missiles would impact before my planes were even discovered by the enemy, wouldn't they?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I know so, Major.  I know so.  And add to that, the whole Air Command force being committed to clobber everything they've got.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But even then, we wouldn't get everything.  I mean some missiles would abort, or they'd miss their targets, or maybe the enemy have some secret bases we don't know about.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You're absolutely right.  You forgot to mention their nuclear subs.  But it wouldn't matter. Sure we wouldn't get off without getting our hair mussed, but we'd prevail.  I don't think we'd lose more than fifty million people, tops.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But if you just let things alone, we wouldn't lose anyone.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Major Mandrake, I guess you don't follow what's going on too closely, do you?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Where, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Where?  Everywhere, Major.  Everywhere.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, I know they've been going on for years, and they haven't gotten any place.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Not yet, Major.  Not yet.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: And I guess they won't until they agree to let us inspect inside their country.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You're very naive, Major.  Don't they say they want disarmament?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  But so do we.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: But we mean it because we are a peace- loving country.  Are they a peace-loving country, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I don't know, sir.  But they're just as anxious to avoid a nuclear war as we are. War just doesn't make sense any more, for anybody.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: But war doesn't make sense precisely because the weapons can kill an entire country -- right?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Then don't you realize the Bomb gives us Peace not War?  And, if that's the case, I ask you again: Why do they want disarmament?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, sir, like I said, for the same reasons we do.  I mean, all the experts say the most likely way for War to start nowadays is by an accident, or a mistake, or by some mentally unbalanced person --

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Go on, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I was just going to say, as long as the weapons exist, sooner or later something's going to happen -- and that'll be it for both countries.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I've heard the arguments.  Like Napoleon's quote, "There's one thing you can't do with a bayonet, and that's - sit on it."

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: That's right, sir.  And don't forget in a few years a lot of other countries will have the bomb.  What if they start something?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Go on, Major.  You fascinate me.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, sir, I remember an example that pointed out that if a system was safe on 99.99% of the days of the year, given average luck it would fail in thirty years.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I still ask, why do they want disarmament?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, for the same reasons we do, sir. Don't you see?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: No, Major, I don't.  They have no regard for human life.  They wouldn't care if they lost their whole country as long as they won.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Gee, sir, that last remark doesn't exactly make all the sense in the world.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Major, you're talking like one of them!

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, I'm not, sir.  Honestly, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Don't be offended, Major.  Our President holds the same views.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Don't you think he knows something about this, General Ripper?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I'll tell you what I do think.  If they say they're for disarmament, I say anyone who says they're for disarmament is either a traitor or a damned fool.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But, General, we're on our toes.  We haven't agreed to anything for years.  Inffact, a a lot of people say we never will.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: But if they suddenly opened up and gave us the inspection we want, we'd agree, wouldn't we?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: If they gave us what we think we need, yes, I guess we would.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: And you'd like to see that?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: General, what's good enough for the President and all the experts he's got working on the thing, is good enough for me.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Do you think we'd cheat?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.  I'm sure we wouldn't.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Do you think they would cheat?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, sir.  I'm no expert on the subject, but I've read some pretty sharp ideas the big boys have.  Like, say, both countries agreeing to a million dollar reward and international protection for anyone who gives evidence of cheating to the inspectors. You can't hide those things without a lot of people knowing about it.  And if I were going to try and hide a few, I wouldn't want to depend on the fact that some poor slob isn't going to run and blab for a million bucks.  We're as smart as they are, and if they cheat, or even hold back information, we'd pull right out.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Major, I hate to say this, but I think you've been enemy indoctrinated, and you don't even know it.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Major, those are my boys out there dying.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  Why don't you stop the fighting, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: To peace on earth, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Peace on earth.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: General, now that you've done that, I beg you to recall the Wing.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Major, I happen to believe in a life after this one, so I believe I will have to answer for what I have done.  I think I can.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: It was a honest mistake, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I presume the planes are armed?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I'm afraid so, Mister Presient. Being part of the air-borne alert, each plane is carrying a full load - about fifty megatons apiece.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Well, what about the Positive Control, the safety catch?  Don't the planes automatically come back unless they get a second order?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: That's right, sir.  But the planes were at their Positive Control points, ready to turn around when General Ripper issued the final Go-code.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: And I suppose there's some reason why you haven't recalled them?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Yes, sir.  The base commander, General Ripper, selected Plan-R?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: What the hell is Plan-R?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, sir, Plan-R is an emergency plan to be used by lower echelon commanders if higher echelons have been knocked out by a sneak attack.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Why can't you cancel it?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Once the orders have been given, Plan-R requires any new orders to be received on the CRM-114 in the aircraft.  But the CRM-114 will not receive any transmissions unless they are preceded by the proper three-letter code group.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: And I suppose you're going to tell me you don't know what the three-letter code is.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Mister President, to guard against espionage, the three letter of the code group for Plan-R are always selected by the lower echelon commander himself, just before each mission.  They are sealed in the various attack plans and are known only to the lower echelon commander and his deputy.  In this case the deputy is air-borne with the Wing, and General Ripper refuses to recall the planes.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How soon until the enemy finds out what's going on?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: We estimate the planes should be entering their coastal radar cover in about twenty-five min- utes.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How could you let this happen, General Schmuck?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Mister President, I know you think I've let you down, but we had to have a Plan-R.  If we completely centralized the command and control, all a potential aggressor would have to worry about was knock- ing out maybe half a dozen headquarters and the Capitol, and we'd be out of business. We'd have planes and missiles just sitting there while we were getting clobbered.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Then there's no chance for recall?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I should say practically none, though we have our communications center plowing through every possible three-letter combination. The trouble is that there are about seventeen thousand permutations, and it will take us approximately four and a half days to go through them all.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: General Jack D. Ripper, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I want to talk to General Ripper.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: But we can't communicate with the base.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I don't think that's a fair analogy, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Admiral Buldike?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: But he'll hear everything we're saying.  And if he just looks out of that window, he'll see everything we're doing.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: That's the idea, General Schmuck.  Zlat!

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: We don't operate like you KGB boys.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Knock it off will you, General?  Crudley, find out what's holding up that call!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Have you received acknowledgements from every plane?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: They're coming in now.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How long will it take to receive them all?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I'm not certain, Mister President.  The boys in CONCOM do the pencil work.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I believe it will be just a few minutes, at the most.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How many planes did we lose?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I'm not certain, Mister President.  But I believe it was four.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: General Faceman, what was the name of the officer who called me from Burpelson?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: General Schmuck, are you positive of your figures?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Naturally I am, sir.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: He says they've only shot down three planes.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, if you choose to take his word over mine ---

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Look, he's there, and you're here.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Mister President, there were thirty-four aircraft involved.  Thirty acknowledged the recall.  That makes four shot down.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Hello, are you still there?...Uh-huh...I'll be right back.  We're still working this thing out.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How do you know they were shot down, Buck?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, just common sense, sir.  Thirty from thirty-four equals four, or my name's not "Buck" Schmuck!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, sir, it looks like one aircraft, the "Leper Colony", failed to receive the recall.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Have you tried the recall again?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Yes, sir.  We're still sending it.  But it's a funny thing we don't seem to be able to make any contact with the aircraft at all.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: What's the target.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, the Premier doped it out pretty well. Its primary is their missile base at Laputa.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Is there any chance a single aircraft can penetrate the entire enemy Air Defense, when its course and target are known?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: If I can speak freely, sir -- look, these guys talk big, but frankly, we think they're short of know-how.  You can't just take a bunch of ignorant peasants and expect them to understand a machine like one of our boys, and I don't mean that as an insult, Mister Ambassador.  Hell, we all know what kind of guts your people have.  Why just look how many millions of 'em those Nazis  killed and, hell, they still wouldn't quit.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: General, stick to the point, please.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, sir, if the A/C's a really good man, I mean really sharp, why he can barrel that plane along so low - well you just have to see it some time.  A real big plane, like a Sting Ray, zig-zagging in, its jet exhaust frying chickens in the barnyard ---  Has he a chance?.....Hell, yes!  He has one hell of a chance.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: You've lied to me twice - I'm sorry, but it will be strictly routine.  These men are experts.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Zlat, make sure the secret service boys care- fully search his seven body orifices.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: Yeah, to see if we're on our toes.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: No, they wouldn't send us in with bombs on an exercise.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Give me a first rough course as soon as you can, Lieutenant Ballmuff.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: Roughly, one-zero-five. I'll have it plotted in a minute, Major Kong.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: I've got the heading, Major.  One-three-eight.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Roger. One-three-eight.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: Roger, maintain.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lothar, take your checks now.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: We should be crossing the coast in about six minutes.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Thanks, Binky.  Can you see Bromdingna Island yet?

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: All right...we're still flying.  I'm taking her down to the deck.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Give me revs for maximum speed at sea level.

turns.speaker: LT. BALLMUFF
turns.text: You know what that'll do to our fuel consumption.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Can't help it.  What's the wind like?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: What else could it be?

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Maybe it's an exercise.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: He's right.  We wouldn't have started it.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: They must have clobbered some of our cities already!

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: He's right.  They must have clobbered some of our cities already.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: The dirty, stinking, rotten, sons of B's!! They might have clobbered Marge and the

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Maximum ECM.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Fifteen!  Twelve o' clock.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Then this is it.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: War.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: War?

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: I'm sorry, Major Kong.  I guess I was way out of line.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Forget it, Quentin.  It can happen to the best of us.  Now let's get squared away.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: A through H is correct.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Main interference linked to electronic detector.  Fight interference on readi- ness state.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Missile and plane flight path computer showing four greens.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Zombies set to knock out local air defense four hundred miles from primary.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Missiles!  Sixty miles off, heading in fast.  Steady track, they look like beam riders.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Roger, keep calling them.  Knock off auto-pilot, Ace.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Just the missiles.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: They must have been fired from Bromdingna - probably one of their new Vampire - 202's. They've got a range well over a hundred miles.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Forty-five.  Still coming straight and fast. Twelve o' clock.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Speed?

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Between Mach 3 and 4.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Call them every five miles.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Thirty-five, still straight.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Twenty!  Twelve o' clock.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Maximum ECM!

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Shouldn't be bad.  Might even help.  But my guess is we're going to have to paddle our way back.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: We'll worry about that later.  Okay, I'll take damage reports.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Yeah, I got it in the thigh.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutenant Toejam, why don't you help him?

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Why can't he help me now?  He's sitting two feet away from me!

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Come on, Quentin, isn't that pretty selfish, putting yourself ahead of the mission?

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Look, I'm shot - it hurts.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutenant Quiffer, we're all sorry you were hit, and we'll help you stick it together as soon as we get squared away.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Look, can't someone help me?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Roger.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Fighters closing fast - range fifty miles.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: They must have made a visual contact.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Must be Mach two-five stuff.  Altitude fifteen thousand.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: They can't touch us at this height.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: They're moving apart.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: If they come down low enough to make a firing pass, they'll never be able to pull up in time.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: I think they mean business.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Hang on, boys.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Sorry, King.  My leg's stiff as a board.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Hey, Terry, I'm hit.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Well, listen, King.  Could you take her up to about eight hundred?  That'll help you come in at a nice down-angle, and it'll give us a chance for our chutes to open.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Sure, I'll take her up to eight hundred.

turns.speaker: LT. QUIFFER
turns.text: Could you take her up right now, King?  Other- wise we'll get kind of close to the fireball.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Sure, I'll take her up right now.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Hey, King.  Somebody at Burpelson has a very perverted sense of humor.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: I just got another blast on the CRM-114, and the damned thing decodes: Wing Attack, Plan-R.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Wing attack, Plan-R.  That's exactly what it says.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check your code again.  No one at base would pull a stunt like that, Terry.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: That's what I'm doing, and it comes out the same.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: No, this looks like the real thing.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Yeah, it sure looks like the real thing, all right.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Okay.  Check these points.  Complete radio silence.  To ensure that the enemy can't plant false transmissions and fake orders, the CRM-114 is to be switched into all receiver circuits.  The three code letters of the period are to be set on the alphabet dials of the CRM-114, which will in turn block any transmissions other than those preceded by the code letters. You got it?

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Roger, I'm setting up the CRM-114.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Primary target the ICBM base at Laputa. One weapon fused for air burst at ten thou- sand.  Second weapon to be used if first malfunctions.  Otherwise the secondary gets it - the airfield outside of Karnak.  Fused air burst at ten thousand.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutenant Toejam, are you ready for Bim and Bam?

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Ready, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Primary arming switch.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Primary arming switch.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: I thought I should check out the damage first. My gear is busted up pretty bad.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutenant Toejam's going to help you in a minute.  Can you check your ECM?

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Listen, I think I'm hit bad.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Where'd they get you?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Damn you, Lieutenant Toejam!  Lothar!

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: What does it look like?

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Some kind of signaling.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: No kidding.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Let's see...International Morse, I think ...K...E...O...P...E...R...E...C...A...L... L...M...I...S...T...A...K...E...O...P...E... Gee, I don't know, it seems to be some kind of code.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Yep, it's the CRM-114 code, all right.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Very interesting.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Gee, we hate to leave you like this, Major Kong.  But there isn't anything we can really accomplish by sticking around.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: LT. TOEJAM
turns.text: Listen, King, old buddy.  On behalf---

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Skip it and jump, damn you!  This flak's so close, I can smell it.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: In about twenty minutes we start losing height to keep under coastal radar.  Cross in over the coast low-level, continue low- level on zig-zag legs to primary, and climb for bomb run.  Any questions?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I've got one.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Shoot, Lothar.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Our targets are a missile complex and an airfield - not cities, right?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: That's what I said.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Well, if there's a war, they must have hit us first.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: What's your point, Lothar?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Well, if they hit us first, they've probably fired off their missiles and got their planes off the ground already.  We'll just be hitting empty real estate.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Are you saying our order don't make sense?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Hellnno, Major.  I was just trying to think the thing through.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check target approach.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Bomb doors circuit is green, bomb release circuit is green, bomb fusing circuit is green.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check, all bomb circuits green.  Okay, Lothar.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: When do you want to arm the bomb for the primary, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: As soon as I've checked over the route. About five minutes.  All right?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Primary circuit is live.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Primary trigger switch.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Release first safety.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: First safety.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Second safety.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Seond safety.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Fusing for ten thousand air burst.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Check, ten thousand air burst.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Master safety.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Master Kong.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Primary bomb is live.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: All right, Lothat, that does it.  Master safety on now until bomb run.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Master safety on.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Let's have a rundown on the damage, Lothar?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Everything still checks out okay.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Binky?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Yes, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lothar, get up here fast, and bring your First- Aid kit!  I'm hit kinda bad, I think.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Can't "Ace" help you?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: He's dead.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I bit his jugular vein.  Now will you shut up and get up here???

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Sure!  Sure, I'm on my way.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Where'd they get you?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: In the back...feels like an arrowhead.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: How do you know he's dead?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Hell, he looks dead.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: He's dead, all right.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Listen, give me a shot quick!

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I don't know what we got left besides Bim and Bam.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Quentin, how's your gear?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: No, look!  It's "OPE - Recall Mistake."

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Recall what mistake?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: No, I think it means, "Recall period Mistake," and the OPE is probably the CRM-114 code. Terry?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: You sure have to hand it to those guys.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I mean pulling a stunt like that.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Well, we sure as hell aren't going home just because the enemy tells us to.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Wait a minute, Major.  "OPE," that's the recall code.  Where would they get that?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: You tell me.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: They must have gotten it from the base. No one else would know it.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Why should they call us back?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: How the hell do I know?  Maybe the war's over.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutenant Zogg, what do our orders say about the authentication of orders during an attack mission?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Look, this is different.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Our orders warn us to expect the enemy to use ingenuity in issuing contrary and confusing orders.  And therefore, to disregard anything that doesn't come on the CRM-114.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: But the CRM-114 has been smashed for almost an hour.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Then that settles it, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Like hell it does.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: The CRM-114 is smashed, right?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Right.  So how could we get any messages?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: That's the point.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I don't get you, King.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I said that's the point!

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Look, King, maybe you've lost too much blood, or something.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lieutentant Zogg, how would you like your black butt slung into a General Court Martial when we get back???

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Take it easy, Major Kong.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Then get off my back!

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: There are plenty of traitors and spies running around loose.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: But the code is made up by General Ripper, and he's the only one left at the base who would know the code.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Nobody's loyalty is beyond question.  Besides, how do we know one of his staff didn't see it?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Come on, King.  That doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Okay, how do we know they didn't shoot down one of our planes and torture the crew?  How do we know that?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: We crossed the coast over an hour ago. Okay?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: You're giving them an awful lot of credit for being on the ball.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: First lesson in War College:  Never under- estimate your enemy.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Sorry, King.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Forget it.  Okay, team, let's break it up and get ready for the kick-off.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: It's me - Lothar.  Are you okay?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I'm okay.  What's up?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Well, I hate to say this, but I think the bomb bay doors are stuck.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Well, I can't get out and look, King.  But I don't get a green light.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Maybe the warning system's out.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: But I get a red light.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Have you tried the emergency system?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I tried everything.  Something must have gotten bent or twisted from the pounding we took.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Lothar, can you arm the bombs for impact?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: But I TOLD YOU, I don't think we can get the bomb bay doors open.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I asked you a question, Lothar!

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: But how are we going to drop the bombs if the doors won't ---  Hey, King....you're not thinking of --- You don't mean you'd --- ???

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: There's no other way, Lothar.  Can you re-arm the bombs for impact?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Let me check.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: There's no other way, boys.  I'm going to have to take her in...the hard way.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I think it's okay, King.  They should go off on impact.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Would it matter if they hit at a flat angle? I mean, do you think the deuterium mass might separate from the atomic trigger?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Well, it would probably help if you took it ...sort of...straight down.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Roger.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: We're on course, Major.  Just fixed our position on that river back there.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: What the hell are you doing here, Lothar?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I thought I'd go along for the ride.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Now what the hell did you want to go and do a thing like that for, Lothar?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: I thought maybe you'd like some company.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: King, would you mind if I keep me hands on the wheel when you take her in?

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I'd be mighty proud if you did, Lothar.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Thanks, King.  I've always wanted to take one of these big babies in.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Listen, Lothar.  You know that crack I made about your...butt?

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: I just wanted you to know I didn't mean anything by it.

turns.speaker: LT. ZOGG
turns.text: Sure, King.

turns.speaker: MAJOR KONG
turns.text: Well, I just wanted you to know how I felt. Hell, I know Air Command wouldn't have taken you if you weren't okay.  And don't think I don't know some of our best ball-players and entertainers are of Negro descent.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: At the bottom of mines?

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: Yes.  The radioactivity could not penetrate a mine some thousands of feet deep.

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: In a matter of weeks, sufficient improvements for a dwelling space could be provided.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: But they couldn't come out for a hundred years!

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: Mister President, man is an amazingly adaptable creature.  After all, the conditions would be far superior to those, say, of the Nazi concentration camps, where there is ample evidence most of the wretched creatures clung desperately to life.

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: It would not be difficult.  Nuclear reactors could provide power almost indefinitely. Greenhouses could maintain plant life. Animals could be bred and slaughtered. A quick survey would have to be made of all the suitable minesites in the country, but I shouldn't be surprised if several hundred thousand of our people could be accomodatedd. Every nation would undoubtedly follow suit.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: But who would be chosen?

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: A special committee would have to be appointed to study and recommend the criteria to be employed, but off-hand, I should say that in addition to the factors of youth, health, sexual fertility, intelligence, and a cross-section of necessary skills, it would be absolutely vital that our top government and military men be included, to impart the required principles of leadership and tradition.

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: When they emerge, a good deal of present real estate and machine tools will still be recoverable, if they are moth-balled in advance.  I would guess they could then work their way back to our present gross national product within twenty years.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: But, look here, Von Klutz.  Won't this nucleus of survivors be so shocked, grief-stricken, and anguished that they will envy the dead, and indeed, not wish to go on living?

turns.speaker: VON KLUTZ
turns.text: Certainly not, sir.  When they go down into the mine, everyone else will still be alive.  They will have no shocking memories, and the prevailing emotion should be one of a nostalgia for those

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Uh, yeah, she should be coming by.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Uh, well, what'd she say? Is Pony coming?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: We are?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Alright. She told him to meet us here. Fuck.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Mn-hm.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: "Burger Manifesto, Part One" is gonna make people think?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Um-hm.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Wait. Racism? You don't know anybody who's black!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I just walked all the way from Westside to here. I haven't walked that far since junior high. I thought you didn't drink.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: I don't anymore.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Can I have some?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Knock yourself out.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You know, one moment things are so fucked up than you look at it from a totally different angle and it makes sense.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Did you ever hear that saying, "This too shall pass"?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Sure, all the time, in Group.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: In Group?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Rehab. Outpatient. I have to go once a week. It's kind of like AA.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Oh, yeah, you had to go to Highgate. That must've been intense.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Intense.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How long were you in there?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Uh, ninety days. And now I just have to go once a week. See, I'm rehabilitated.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, you shouldn't drink. Are you gonna drink?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: No. Oh, maybe. Fuck.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I mean, that would suck if you had to go back to rehab.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Yeah, it would suck big time. I'd kill myself first.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It was pretty bad, huh?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: It was like hell with windows. You know, there's shit on the walls. Kids my age sucking their thumbs. I mean, every day I would, I'd wake up in my cell and I'd think, my parents put me here. Why? Why? Because I stayed out all night one time. Uh, because I broke the VCR when I was drunk. Because I was out of control. I thought my parents loved me.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: We were all riding around and it suddenly hit me what we were doing. We were getting off on the fact that we're in a car teen feet longer than all the rest. And I got out and I just started walking.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, what it was... I, I don't want to admit it, but, you know, I was jealous of Pony.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Well, sure, he's rich and he's famous. He's got everything and you've got nothing.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah, but, when I was walking, I realized that he's stuck in that limo all the time. He's stuck with his interviews, he's stuck with his autograph, he has to do whatever his manager tells him to do, you know? He's not free. He's just part of the machine, and if you think about it, freedom's all that there really is.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Yeah, I guess.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You know? And it used to scare me so much that I didn't know what was coming in my life.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Mm-hm.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You know, like, like, I would always think, uh, you know, what if I make the wrong move? But maybe there isn't any right move. You know? I mean, look at us. You know, we all dress the same, we all talk the same, we all fuck the same, we all watch the same TV. Nobody's really different, even if they think they're different. "Oh, boy, look at my tattoo, you know?" And see, that's what makes me freak. Because I can do anything I want, as long as I don't care about the result.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: That was really great.

turns.speaker: SOOZE
turns.text: Was it okay?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: SOOZE
turns.text: What did you guys think?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Slides go with it.

turns.speaker: SOOZE
turns.text: Behind me. I'm making these slides out of these old pictures and paintings and stuff.

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: It's called "Burger Manifesto, Part One The Dialectical Expression of Testosterone." Isn't that a great title?

turns.speaker: SOOZE
turns.text: Why is everything about you, Jeff?

turns.speaker: BEE-BEE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: SOOZE
turns.text: I stand for something. And I'm trying to communicate something.
